snippet: The agency has trained thousands of Afghan fighters for counterterrorism pursuit teams, but some Afghan officials say they are largely unaccountable to the government.
abstract: CIA-trained Afghan counterterrorism units draw criticism after series of raids that killed six innocent civilians; clunky transfer of power to Afghan authorities left teams with ambiguous status and oversight; some officials cite units' effectiveness in fighting Taliban as indispensable.

byline.contributor: Farooq Jan Mangal contributed reporting from Khost Province, Rod Nordland from Kabul, and Mark Mazzetti from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The agency has trained thousands of Afghan fighters for counterterrorism pursuit teams, but some Afghan officials say they are largely unaccountable to the government.

headline.main: Civilian Deaths Raise Questions About C.I.A.-Trained Forces in Afghanistan
